title: How to Run Orchestration Tests
content:
# How to Run Orchestration Tests

Guide for running the orchestration E2E test suite, which validates the full orchestration lifecycle: task creation, daemon dispatch, worker execution, and steward review.

## Overview

The test suite has two modes:
- **Mock mode** (default): Uses a mock session manager. Fast, no external dependencies.
- **Real mode**: Spawns actual `claude` processes via `SpawnerService`. Requires `claude` in PATH.

All 12 tests support both modes. Mock mode simulates agent behavior; real mode lets Claude actually execute tasks.

## Quick Start

### Run all tests (mock mode)

```bash
bun run test:orchestration
```

### Run all tests (real mode)

```bash
bun run test:orchestration --mode real --verbose
```

## CLI Flags

| Flag | Short | Description |
|------|-------|-------------|
| `--mode <mock\|real>` | `-m` | Test mode (default: `mock`) |
| `--test <id>` | `-t` | Run specific test by ID (substring match) |
| `--tag <tag>` | | Filter tests by tag (`director`, `worker`, `steward`, `daemon`) |
| `--bail` | | Stop on first failure |
| `--verbose` | `-v` | Enable verbose logging |
| `--timeout <ms>` | | Override timeout for each test |
| `--skip-cleanup` | | Preserve temp workspace after run (for debugging) |
| `--help` | `-h` | Show help |

## Examples

### Run a single test

```bash
bun run test:orchestration --test "worker-marks-task-complete"
```

### Run tests by category

```bash
bun run test:orchestration --tag worker
bun run test:orchestration --tag director
bun run test:orchestration --tag steward
bun run test:orchestration --tag daemon
```

### Run real mode with bail and debugging

```bash
bun run test:orchestration --mode real --tag worker --bail --verbose --skip-cleanup
```

When `--skip-cleanup` is used, the temp workspace path is printed so you can inspect the git repo, worktrees, and database.

## Test List

| # | ID | Tags | What it validates |
|---|-----|------|-------------------|
| 1 | `director-creates-tasks` | director, task | Director creates a task from a prompt |
| 2 | `director-creates-plans` | director, plan | Director creates a multi-task plan |
| 3 | `daemon-dispatches-worker` | daemon, dispatch, worker | Daemon assigns unassigned task to available worker |
| 4 | `daemon-respects-dependencies` | daemon, dependencies | Blocked task waits until dependency resolves |
| 5 | `worker-uses-worktree` | worker, worktree, git | Worker operates in an isolated git worktree |
| 6 | `worker-commits-work` | worker, git, commit | Worker commits changes to its worktree branch |
| 7 | `worker-creates-merge-request` | worker, merge-request, git | Worker sets branch/MR metadata on task completion |
| 8 | `worker-marks-task-complete` | worker, task, completion | Task status transitions to closed |
| 9 | `worker-handoff-context` | worker, handoff, context | Worker creates handoff before context exhaustion |
| 10 | `daemon-spawns-steward-mr` | daemon, steward, merge-request | Merge request event triggers steward spawn |
| 11 | `steward-merges-passing` | steward, merge, tests | Steward merges PR when tests pass |
| 12 | `steward-handoff-failing` | steward, handoff, tests | Steward hands off to worker when tests fail |

## Timeouts

Mock mode uses per-test timeouts (30s-120s). Real mode applies longer category-based defaults:

| Category | Real mode timeout |
|----------|------------------|
| Director tests (1-2) | 240s |
| Daemon tests (3-4) | 180s |
| Worker tests (5-9) | 300s |
| Steward tests (10-12) | 300s |

Use `--timeout <ms>` to override.

## Test Environment

Each test run creates an isolated temporary workspace with:
- Fresh git repository with initial commit
- Local bare remote (`.test-remote.git`) for push operations
- Minimal project structure (`package.json`, `src/index.ts`, `README.md`)
- SQLite database in `.elemental/elemental.db`
- All orchestration services (daemon, agent registry, worktree manager, etc.)

In real mode, constrained prompt overrides are written to `.elemental/prompts/` to guide agents toward fast, deterministic behavior.

## Key Files

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/testing/test-context.ts` | Test workspace setup, mode toggle, cleanup |
| `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/testing/orchestration-tests.ts` | All 12 test definitions (mock + real paths) |
| `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/testing/test-utils.ts` | Polling helpers and assertions |
| `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/testing/test-prompts.ts` | Constrained prompts for real-mode agents |
| `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/cli/commands/test-orchestration.ts` | CLI runner and flag parsing |
| `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/testing/index.ts` | Public exports |

## Troubleshooting

**Tests pass in mock but fail in real mode**: Real mode depends on `claude` being installed and accessible. Verify with `which claude`.

**Orphan processes after interrupted run**: The cleanup handler registers SIGINT/SIGTERM handlers, but if the process is killed with SIGKILL, orphan `claude` processes may remain. Check with `ps aux | grep claude` and kill manually.

**Debugging a failing test**: Use `--skip-cleanup` to preserve the workspace, then inspect the git log, worktrees, and database in the temp directory.

title: Platform Reference
How to Work with Dependencies
Prompts System Reference
content:
# Prompts System Reference

**Directory:** `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/prompts/`

Built-in role definition prompts and customization system.

## Overview

The prompts system provides:
- Built-in role prompts for director, worker, and steward agents
- Project-level override support
- Prompt composition with task context
- Steward focus-specific addenda

## Prompt Files

```
packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/prompts/
â”œâ”€â”€ index.ts              # Loading and composition API
â”œâ”€â”€ director.md           # Director role prompt
â”œâ”€â”€ worker.md             # Ephemeral worker role prompt
â”œâ”€â”€ persistent-worker.md  # Persistent worker role prompt
â”œâ”€â”€ message-triage.md     # Message triage prompt (used by triage sessions)
â”œâ”€â”€ steward-base.md       # Base steward prompt
â”œâ”€â”€ steward-merge.md      # Merge focus addendum
â”œâ”€â”€ steward-health.md     # Health focus addendum
â”œâ”€â”€ steward-ops.md        # Ops focus addendum
â”œâ”€â”€ steward-reminder.md   # Reminder focus addendum
â””â”€â”€ steward-docs.md       # Docs focus addendum
```

## Loading Prompts

### Basic Loading

```typescript
import {
  loadRolePrompt,
  loadBuiltInPrompt,
  hasBuiltInPrompt,
  listBuiltInPrompts,
} from '@elemental/orchestrator-sdk';

// Load prompt (checks project overrides first)
const result = loadRolePrompt('worker', undefined, {
  projectRoot: '/my/project',
});
console.log(result?.prompt);   // The prompt content
console.log(result?.source);   // 'built-in' or path to override

// Load persistent worker prompt
const persistent = loadRolePrompt('worker', undefined, {
  projectRoot: '/my/project',
  workerMode: 'persistent',
});
// Returns: persistent-worker.md instead of worker.md

// Load built-in only (skip overrides)
const builtIn = loadBuiltInPrompt('director');

// For stewards, specify focus
const mergePrompt = loadRolePrompt('steward', 'merge');
// Returns: steward-base.md + steward-merge.md combined

// Check existence
hasBuiltInPrompt('worker');                      // true
hasBuiltInPrompt('worker', undefined, 'persistent'); // true
hasBuiltInPrompt('steward', 'merge');            // true

// List all prompts
const files = listBuiltInPrompts();
// ['director.md', 'worker.md', 'steward-base.md', ...]
```

### RolePromptResult

```typescript
interface RolePromptResult {
  prompt: string;                    // Combined prompt content
  source: 'built-in' | string;       // Source path or 'built-in'
  baseSource?: 'built-in' | string;  // For stewards: base source
  focusSource?: 'built-in' | string; // For stewards: focus source
}
```

## Building Agent Prompts

Compose complete startup prompts with task context:

```typescript
import { buildAgentPrompt } from '@elemental/orchestrator-sdk';

// Basic prompt
const prompt = buildAgentPrompt({
  role: 'worker',
  projectRoot: '/my/project',
});

// With task context
const prompt = buildAgentPrompt({
  role: 'worker',
  taskContext: 'Implement user login with OAuth.',
  projectRoot: '/my/project',
});

// With additional instructions
const prompt = buildAgentPrompt({
  role: 'worker',
  taskContext: 'Implement feature X',
  additionalInstructions: 'Focus on test coverage.',
  projectRoot: '/my/project',
});

// Steward with focus
const prompt = buildAgentPrompt({
  role: 'steward',
  stewardFocus: 'merge',
  projectRoot: '/my/project',
});

// Skip project overrides
const prompt = buildAgentPrompt({
  role: 'worker',
  builtInOnly: true,
});
```

### BuildAgentPromptOptions

```typescript
interface BuildAgentPromptOptions {
  role: AgentRole;
  stewardFocus?: StewardFocus;
  workerMode?: WorkerMode;       // 'ephemeral' | 'persistent'
  taskContext?: string;
  additionalInstructions?: string;
  projectRoot?: string;
  builtInOnly?: boolean;
}
```

## Project-Level Overrides

Override built-in prompts by placing files in `.elemental/prompts/`:

```
my-project/
â”œâ”€â”€ .elemental/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ prompts/
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ worker.md           # Custom worker prompt
â”‚       â””â”€â”€ steward-merge.md    # Custom merge steward addendum
â””â”€â”€ src/
```

The loader checks for project overrides first, then falls back to built-in.

**Steward overrides are independent:** You can override just the base, just the focus, or both.

## Prompt Structure

Built-in prompts follow a consistent structure:

### 1. Identity Section
```markdown
# Your Role: {Role}

You are a {role} agent in the Elemental system.
- You own: {responsibilities}
- You report to: {supervisor}
```

### 2. System Overview
```markdown
## System Overview

| Role | Owns | Reports To |
|------|------|------------|
| Director | Plans, priorities | Human |
| Worker | Task execution | Director |
| Steward | Maintenance | Director |
```

### 3. Core Workflows
```markdown
## Core Workflows

### Starting a Task
1. Check inbox for assigned tasks
2. Read task description and requirements
3. Create implementation plan
...
```

### 4. Judgment Scenarios
```markdown
## Decision Making

### When stuck on a task
- Break down into smaller subtasks
- Check for related completed tasks
- Request help from director if blocked > 30 min
```

### 5. CLI Quick Reference
```markdown
## CLI Commands

| Command | Purpose |
|---------|---------|
| `el task ready` | List ready tasks |
| `el task close <id>` | Close task |
```

## Notable Prompt Sections

### message-triage.md

Used by triage sessions spawned by the dispatch daemon. Provides instructions for evaluating incoming messages, categorizing them by urgency and type, and producing structured triage results. Triage sessions run in read-only worktrees and do not perform any task execution.

### Persistent Worker Prompt

The persistent worker prompt (`persistent-worker.md`) is loaded when `workerMode` is `'persistent'`. It differs from the ephemeral worker prompt in several ways:

- Workers receive direct instructions from the human operator (not daemon-dispatched tasks)
- Work is merged via `el merge` (squash merge into master), not `el task complete`
- Discovered issues are reported to the Director via messages, not created as tasks
- No auto-shutdown, handoff, or nudge response sections
- Workers operate in a dedicated worktree on a `session/{name}-{timestamp}` branch

### Worker Prompt: Proactive Communication

The worker prompt (`worker.md`) includes a **Proactive Communication** section that instructs workers on when and how to proactively send status updates to the director. This covers situations such as reporting progress on long-running tasks, flagging potential blockers early, and communicating completion status.

### Worker Prompt: Channel Discipline

The worker prompt (`worker.md`) includes a **Channel Discipline** section that defines rules for which communication channels workers should use. Workers are instructed to keep task-related communication in the appropriate channels and avoid cross-posting or using incorrect channels for status updates, help requests, or task completion notifications.

### Director Prompt: Channel Management

The director prompt (`director.md`) includes a **Channel Management** section that provides the director with guidelines for managing communication channels across the team. This covers creating and organizing channels, routing messages to the correct recipients, and ensuring workers and stewards use appropriate channels for their communications.

## Integration with Spawner

Use `buildAgentPrompt` when spawning agents:

```typescript
import { buildAgentPrompt } from '@elemental/orchestrator-sdk';

const prompt = buildAgentPrompt({
  role: 'worker',
  taskContext: taskDescription,
  projectRoot: workspace,
});

const result = await spawner.spawn(agentId, 'worker', {
  initialPrompt: prompt,
  workingDirectory: worktreePath,
});
```

## Steward Focus Types

| Focus | File | Purpose |
|-------|------|---------|
| `merge` | `steward-merge.md` | Merge completed branches |
| `health` | `steward-health.md` | Monitor agent health |
| `ops` | `steward-ops.md` | Operational tasks |
| `reminder` | `steward-reminder.md` | Send reminders |
| `docs` | `steward-docs.md` | Scan and fix documentation issues |

Steward prompts are combined: `steward-base.md` + `steward-{focus}.md`

## Agent Identity in Prompts

When agents are spawned, their entity ID and the director's ID are automatically included in the prompt for traceability:

| Role | Fields | Location |
|------|--------|----------|
| Director | `**Director ID:** {agentId}` | After role prompt |
| Worker | `**Worker ID:** {agentId}`, `**Director ID:** {directorId}` | In task assignment section |
| Steward | `**Worker ID:** {agentId}`, `**Director ID:** {directorId}` | In task/merge assignment section |
| Triage | `**Worker ID:** {agentId}`, `**Director ID:** {directorId}` | In session context section |

This allows agents to identify themselves and know their director for escalation and communication.

## Best Practices

1. **Keep prompts concise:** Built-in prompts are additive to Claude Code's system prompt. Focus on role-specific guidance.

2. **Use behaviors for context:** Use `AgentBehaviors` in role definitions for event-specific instructions rather than bloating the main prompt.

3. **Override sparingly:** Only override built-in prompts when you need different behavior. Partial overrides (just focus, not base) work well.

4. **Include CLI commands:** Prompts should remind agents of key CLI commands they'll use.

5. **Test with real agents:** Verify prompt effectiveness by running agents and observing behavior.

## Loading Options

```typescript
interface LoadPromptOptions {
  projectRoot?: string;      // Project root for override lookup
  builtInOnly?: boolean;     // Skip project overrides
  workerMode?: WorkerMode;   // 'ephemeral' | 'persistent' (for worker role)
}
```

## API Reference

```typescript
// Load prompt with override support
loadRolePrompt(
  role: AgentRole,
  stewardFocus?: StewardFocus,
  options?: LoadPromptOptions
): RolePromptResult | undefined

// Load built-in only
loadBuiltInPrompt(
  role: AgentRole,
  stewardFocus?: StewardFocus,
  workerMode?: WorkerMode
): string | undefined

// Check existence
hasBuiltInPrompt(
  role: AgentRole,
  stewardFocus?: StewardFocus,
  workerMode?: WorkerMode
): boolean

// List all prompt files
listBuiltInPrompts(): string[]

// Build complete prompt
buildAgentPrompt(
  options: BuildAgentPromptOptions
): string | undefined
```

Found pre-existing issue during review of el-2bes: The @elemental/web tests fail in worktrees because node_modules is missing and playwright is not installed. Workers report that worktrees are missing node_modules and Playwright binaries. The test output shows 'playwright: command not found' and 'Local package.json exists, but node_modules missing'. This affects all worktrees.

Prior tasks (el-26jn, el-fux8) fixed pnpm symlink resolution and package.json exports, but the root issue remains: dependencies are not installed in worktrees after creation.

## Root Cause
When a worktree is created via `git worktree add`, it gets a copy of the source tree but no node_modules. pnpm install and playwright install need to be run in the worktree.

## Approach
1. Search workspace docs first (`el document search "worktree"`, `el document search "agent spawn"`)
2. Find where worktrees are created in the orchestration system (likely in the runtime or agent spawning code)
3. Add a post-worktree-creation step that runs `pnpm install` (and `npx playwright install` if needed) inside the worktree
4. Alternatively, configure pnpm to share the store across worktrees so symlinks resolve correctly
5. Test by creating a worktree and verifying tests pass

## Acceptance Criteria
- After a worktree is created by the orchestration system, `node_modules` is present and resolvable
- Tests (including Playwright e2e tests) can run in worktrees without 'command not found' or missing module errors
- No regressions in the main checkout

## Problem
The orchestrator server emits `MaxListenersExceededWarning` because event listeners accumulate without cleanup in the session manager's event forwarding.

## Root Cause
In `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/runtime/session-manager.ts`, the `setupSessionEventForwarding()` method (around line 1196) attaches **7 event listeners** per spawned session (`event`, `pty-data`, `error`, `exit`, `stderr`, `raw`, and a **duplicate** `pty-data` at ~line 1287). These listeners are never explicitly removed when sessions terminate.

With Node.js's default max of 10 listeners, spawning just 2 concurrent sessions triggers the warning.

A secondary contributor is in `apps/orchestrator-server/src/services.ts` (~lines 164-176): the `onResultEvent` listener added per dispatched session is only removed when a 'result' event fires. If a session terminates without emitting 'result', the listener leaks.

## What to Do
1. **Remove the duplicate `pty-data` listener** (~line 1287 in session-manager.ts)
2. **Add cleanup** in `setupSessionEventForwarding()`: return a cleanup function that calls `.off()` for all attached listeners, and call it when the session exits/terminates
3. **Fix the `onResultEvent` leak** in services.ts: ensure the listener is removed on session exit, not just on 'result' event
4. **Do NOT just increase `setMaxListeners()`** â€” that masks the leak. Fix the root cause.

## Acceptance Criteria
- No `MaxListenersExceededWarning` when running the orchestrator server with multiple concurrent sessions
- All event listeners attached in `setupSessionEventForwarding()` are cleaned up when a session terminates
- The duplicate `pty-data` listener is removed
- The `onResultEvent` listener in services.ts is cleaned up on session exit
- Existing tests pass (`bun test src` from orchestrator-sdk)

## Relevant Files
- `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/runtime/session-manager.ts` â€” `setupSessionEventForwarding()`
- `apps/orchestrator-server/src/services.ts` â€” `onResultEvent` listener

## Documentation
- Search workspace docs before starting: `el document search "session manager"`, `el document search "event"`
- Update Documentation Directory (el-30yb) if new docs are created

## Problem
The dispatch daemon currently forwards inbox messages directly to the director's CLI session via `sessionManager.messageSession()`. This interrupts the director's workflow by injecting unsolicited messages as user input into the running session.

## Current Behavior
In `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/services/dispatch-daemon.ts`:
1. `pollInboxes()` (~line 542) polls all agents including the director
2. `processInboxItem()` routes director messages to `processPersistentAgentMessage()` (~line 1830)
3. `processPersistentAgentMessage()` (~line 1875) forwards messages directly to the director's PTY session and marks them as read

This means the director doesn't control when it processes messages â€” the daemon pushes them in.

## Desired Behavior
The dispatch daemon should **skip directors** when forwarding inbox messages. The director should surface its own messages by checking its inbox at natural breakpoints (e.g., `el inbox <director-id>`).

## What to Do
1. In `processInboxItem()` (~line 1801), add a guard that skips message forwarding when the agent's role is `'director'`. Leave the inbox item as unread so the director can pick it up manually.
2. Do NOT change how other roles (ephemeral workers, persistent workers, stewards) receive messages â€” only skip directors.
3. The director's prompt already instructs it to check its inbox regularly, so no additional mechanism is needed.

## Acceptance Criteria
- The dispatch daemon does not forward messages to director sessions
- Director inbox items remain unread until the director explicitly reads them
- Ephemeral workers, persistent workers, and stewards continue to receive forwarded messages as before
- Existing tests pass (`bun test src` from orchestrator-sdk)

## Relevant Files
- `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/services/dispatch-daemon.ts` â€” `processInboxItem()`, `processPersistentAgentMessage()`

Found pre-existing issue during review of el-535g: The apps/web test suite has a test isolation problem - the global-setup.ts attempts to create an 'operator' entity but fails with 'Entity with name operator already exists' if the test database from a previous run still exists. The globalSetup should either clean up the test database first or check if the entity already exists before creating. This is NOT blocking the current fix (which correctly resolves the import issue). Please create a task to address the test database isolation problem.

## Problem

The `apps/web` test suite's `global-setup.ts` attempts to create an 'operator' entity unconditionally. If a test database from a previous run still exists (e.g. in `.elemental-test/`), the setup fails with 'Entity with name operator already exists'.

This is a pre-existing test isolation issue reported by el-5r5b during work on el-535g.

## Approach

Either:
1. **Clean up the test database** at the start of global-setup (delete/recreate the `.elemental-test/` directory), OR
2. **Make entity creation idempotent** â€” check if the entity already exists before creating it (upsert pattern)

Option 1 is likely simpler and more robust since it guarantees a clean slate for each test run. Check how `apps/orchestrator-web` handles this for consistency.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `bun test` in `apps/web` passes reliably on repeated runs without manual DB cleanup
- global-setup.ts handles pre-existing test databases gracefully
- No regression in other test suites

title: Resolved: Monaco typecheck issue was false positive
content: The Monaco typecheck issue reported in el-50eh (missing @codingame/monaco-vscode-* module declarations) was a false positive. Investigation found: 1) The @codingame/monaco-vscode-* packages are correctly installed in apps/orchestrator-web/node_modules 2) These packages include type declarations 3) The tsconfig.json has skipLibCheck: true which correctly handles internal type compatibility issues in the monaco-vscode packages 4) Running npx turbo run typecheck --filter=@elemental/orchestrator-web passes without errors. The issue was likely caused by stale cache or missing node_modules at the time of the report.

## Background

Task el-3hg6 changed the dispatch daemon to skip director roles during inbox forwarding. The code is merged but the documentation was never updated to reflect this behavior change.

## Required Changes

### 1. `docs/ORCHESTRATION_PLAN.md` (around lines 210-216)

**Current:**
```markdown
**Process for Persistent Workers and Directors:**
1. Poll for unread messages in inbox
2. For each unread message:
   - Check if agent has active session
   - **If active session:** Forward message to session as user input
   - **If no active session:** Message waits until session starts
3. Mark forwarded messages as read
```

**Change to:**
```markdown
**Process for Persistent Workers:**
1. Poll for unread messages in inbox
2. For each unread message:
   - Check if agent has active session
   - **If active session:** Forward message to session as user input
   - **If no active session:** Message waits until session starts
3. Mark forwarded messages as read

**Process for Directors:**
Directors are **skipped** by the dispatch daemon's inbox polling. Messages remain unread in the director's inbox until the director explicitly checks them at natural breakpoints (e.g., \`el inbox <director-id>\`). This prevents interrupting the director's workflow with unsolicited messages injected as user input.
```

### 2. `docs/reference/orchestrator-services.md` (around lines 346-348)

**Current:**
```markdown
For persistent workers and directors:
- Active session = forward message as user input
- No active session = message waits
```

**Change to:**
```markdown
For persistent workers:
- Active session = forward message as user input
- No active session = message waits

For directors:
- Messages are **not forwarded** â€” directors are skipped by inbox polling
- Messages remain unread until the director checks its inbox manually
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- Both files updated as described above
- No other changes needed â€” this is a docs-only task

## Documentation

- Also update workspace doc el-68pw (Orchestration Architecture) if it mentions director inbox forwarding
- Search workspace docs: `el document search "director inbox"` and `el document search "dispatch daemon"`
- Update the Documentation Directory (el-30yb) if new docs are created
- Add any new documents to the Documentation library (`el library add el-2rig <doc-id>`)

## Bug

The ActiveAgentCard on the Activity page displays "> idle..." even when an agent is actively executing tools. This happens because events without text content (e.g. tool_use events) are filtered out before reaching the card.

## Root Cause

In `apps/orchestrator-web/src/api/hooks/useActiveAgentOutputs.ts` (line ~44), the hook skips events where `!event.content`:

```typescript
if (!event.agentId || !event.content) continue;
```

Many agent events (tool_use, some tool_result, system events) have no `message` text, so they get filtered. When an agent starts a session and immediately uses tools before emitting any text, `lastOutput` stays undefined, and the card falls through to the "> idle..." fallback in `ActiveAgentCard.tsx`.

## Fix

Two complementary changes:

### 1. Show tool activity in useActiveAgentOutputs (`apps/orchestrator-web/src/api/hooks/useActiveAgentOutputs.ts`)
- When an event has no `content` but has a `type` of `tool_use` or `tool_result`, generate a synthetic display string (e.g. "Using Bash...", "Tool completed")
- Use `event.tool` name if available for more descriptive output
- Always update the map entry timestamp so the card knows the agent is active

### 2. Add "working" fallback in ActiveAgentCard (`apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/activity/ActiveAgentCard.tsx`)
- When `lastOutput` is undefined but the session status is `running`, show "> working..." instead of "> idle..."
- Keep "> idle..." only for when the session is truly idle (status is `idle` or `suspended`)

## Key Files
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/api/hooks/useActiveAgentOutputs.ts` â€” event filtering logic
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/activity/ActiveAgentCard.tsx` â€” display fallback logic
- `apps/orchestrator-server/src/routes/events.ts` â€” SSE event streaming (maps `event.message` to `content`)

## Acceptance Criteria
- Agent card shows tool activity (e.g. "> Using Bash...") when agent is executing tools
- Agent card shows "> working..." when session is running but no output received yet
- Agent card still shows "> idle..." only when session is genuinely idle
- No regressions in existing activity page behavior

## Problem

When a merge steward hands off a task (via `el task handoff`), the task stays in `status=REVIEW` with `mergeStatus=testing`. This makes the task invisible to the worker dispatch daemon (`api.ready()` only returns OPEN/IN_PROGRESS tasks) but still visible to the merge steward (`getTasksAwaitingMerge()` queries REVIEW + pending/testing). The stuck merge recovery then resets mergeStatus to pending, and the steward picks it up again â€” creating an infinite loop where no worker ever acts on the review feedback.

## Root Cause

`handoffTask()` in `task-assignment-service.ts:559-636` only clears `assignee` and updates metadata. It does NOT change `task.status` or `mergeStatus`. The task stays in REVIEW, which workers never see.

## Required Changes

In `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/services/task-assignment-service.ts`, modify `handoffTask()` (line 632) to also set:
- `status: TaskStatus.OPEN` â€” so `api.ready()` returns it and the dispatch daemon assigns it to a worker
- `mergeStatus: undefined` (or remove it) in the orchestrator metadata â€” so the merge steward does NOT pick it up

The update call at line 632 should change from:
```typescript
return this.api.update<Task>(taskId, {
  assignee: undefined,
  metadata: newMeta,
});
```

To something like:
```typescript
return this.api.update<Task>(taskId, {
  assignee: undefined,
  status: TaskStatus.OPEN,
  metadata: newMeta, // with mergeStatus cleared
});
```

And the `metaUpdates` block (lines 611-622) should include `mergeStatus: undefined`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- After a steward calls `el task handoff`, the task has `status=OPEN` and no `mergeStatus` (or a value the steward ignores)
- The dispatch daemon's `pollWorkerAvailability()` picks up the handed-off task and assigns it to a worker
- The merge steward's `getTasksAwaitingMerge()` does NOT return handed-off tasks
- Existing worker-to-worker handoff behavior is unaffected (worker handoffs already happen on IN_PROGRESS tasks, which is fine)
- Update existing tests in `task-assignment-service.test.ts` (the `handoffTask` describe block starting around line 305) to assert the new status and mergeStatus
- All tests pass: `bun test src` from `packages/orchestrator-sdk`
- `npx turbo run typecheck` passes

## Key Files
- `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/services/task-assignment-service.ts` â€” `handoffTask()` method (lines 559-636)
- `packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/services/task-assignment-service.test.ts` â€” handoff tests (line 305+)

- Update any docs that describe the task lifecycle or merge status flow
- Update Documentation Directory (el-30yb) if new docs are created

## Problem
The file editor in orchestrator-web is completely broken: white background, no syntax highlighting, lost keystrokes, no LSP. Root cause: the `@codingame/monaco-vscode-*` v25.1.2 service override layer is fundamentally incompatible â€” it replaces Monaco's standalone services (theme, editor, etc.) with VSCode services that don't expose the same APIs.

## Solution
Replace the `@codingame/monaco-vscode-editor-api` integration with `@monaco-editor/react` (already installed at ^4.7.0 but currently unused). This gives us working theming, syntax highlighting, and reliable input handling out of the box.

## Changes Required

### 1. Rewrite `apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/editor/LspMonacoEditor.tsx`
Replace the entire component with a `@monaco-editor/react` based implementation:
- Import `Editor, loader` from `@monaco-editor/react` and `import * as monaco from 'monaco-editor'`
- Keep the EXACT same props interface (`LspMonacoEditorProps`) so the editor page doesn't change
- Keep the `defineCustomTheme` function but call it via `loader.init().then(monaco => defineCustomTheme(monaco))` or in the `beforeMount` callback â€” standard Monaco `defineTheme` works fine with this package
- Use the `<Editor />` component with: `theme='elemental-dark'`, `defaultLanguage={language}`, `value={value}`, `onChange={onChange}`, `options={...}` carrying over all existing editor options (minimap, font, bracket pairs, etc.)
- For the `onMount` prop: use `@monaco-editor/react`'s `onMount={(editor, monaco) => onMount?.(editor, monaco)}`
- Keep the loading spinner (Editor has a `loading` prop)
- Keep the error boundary UI
- Keep the memo wrapper

### 2. Update `apps/orchestrator-web/src/routes/editor/index.tsx`
- Change the type import on line 21 from `import type * as monaco from '@codingame/monaco-vscode-editor-api'` to `import type * as monaco from 'monaco-editor'`
- Remove the import of `isLspSupportedLanguage` from `../../lib/monaco-lsp` (line 48) â€” it's only used to show an LSP status badge (line 834). Replace that check with a simple inline check: `['typescript','javascript','typescriptreact','javascriptreact'].includes(activeTab.language)`

### 3. Update `apps/orchestrator-web/vite.config.ts`
- Remove the `@codingame/esbuild-import-meta-url-plugin` import (line 5)
- Replace the `'monaco-core'` and `'monaco-services'` manual chunks (lines 57-64) with: `'monaco-editor': ['monaco-editor', '@monaco-editor/react']`
- Remove `esbuildOptions: { plugins: [importMetaUrlPlugin] }` from `optimizeDeps` (lines 79-81)
- Remove `worker: { format: 'es' }` (lines 36-38) â€” no longer needed without @codingame workers

### 4. Delete unused LSP files
- Delete `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lsp-setup.ts`
- Delete `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lsp-editor.ts`
- Delete `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/use-lsp-editor.ts`
- Delete `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/README.md`
- Keep `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/languages.ts` (pure utility, no @codingame deps)
- Update `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/index.ts` to only export from `languages.ts`

### 5. Remove unused @codingame packages from package.json

## Goal
Add HTTP API routes to orchestrator-server for browsing, reading, writing, and searching workspace files. The server runs locally and has full filesystem access â€” these routes replace the browser's File System Access API.

## Context
The editor currently uses the browser's File System Access API (FSAPI) to read/write local files. FSAPI is Chromium-only and can't support LSP module resolution. We're migrating to server-side filesystem access so the editor works in all browsers and can support a server-side TypeScript LSP.

The orchestrator-server already runs on the local machine with a known workspace root. It uses the Hono framework. See existing routes in `apps/orchestrator-server/src/routes/` for patterns.

## Routes to Add

Create a new route file: `apps/orchestrator-server/src/routes/workspace-files.ts`

### 1. `GET /api/workspace/tree`
Returns the recursive directory tree of the workspace.

Query params:
- `root` (optional) â€” subdirectory path relative to workspace root, defaults to `'.'`
- `depth` (optional) â€” max recursion depth, defaults to `10`

Response: `{ entries: FileEntry[] }`
```ts
interface FileEntry {
  name: string;        // filename
  path: string;        // relative path from workspace root
  type: 'file' | 'directory';
  size?: number;       // bytes, files only
  lastModified?: number; // unix timestamp ms
  children?: FileEntry[]; // directories only
}
```

Must skip ignored directories: `node_modules`, `.git`, `dist`, `build`, `.next`, `coverage`, `__pycache__`, `.vscode`, `.idea`, `.DS_Store`, `.elemental-worktrees`. Use a constant array for the ignore list.

Use `fs.readdir` with `withFileTypes: true` for efficient directory scanning. Sort: directories first, then alphabetical.

### 2. `GET /api/workspace/file`
Reads a single file's content.

Query params:
- `path` (required) â€” file path relative to workspace root

Response: `{ content: string, name: string, path: string, size: number, lastModified: number }`

**Security:** Validate that the resolved path is within the workspace root (prevent path traversal with `../`). Return 400 for paths outside the workspace. Return 404 if file doesn't exist. Return 413 if file exceeds 5MB.

### 3. `PUT /api/workspace/file`
Writes content to a file.

Body: `{ path: string, content: string }`

Response: `{ success: true, path: string, bytesWritten: number }`

**Security:** Same path traversal protection as read. Create parent directories if they don't exist (`fs.mkdir recursive`).

### 4. `POST /api/workspace/search`
Searches file contents across the workspace. This replaces the client-side file-by-file search.

Body:
```ts
{
  query: string;          // search string
  isRegex?: boolean;      // treat query as regex
  caseSensitive?: boolean;
  wholeWord?: boolean;
  includePattern?: string; // glob pattern for files to include
  excludePattern?: string; // glob pattern for files to exclude
  maxResults?: number;     // default 200
}
```

Response:
```ts
{
  results: Array<{
    path: string;
    matches: Array<{
      line: number;
      column: number;
      length: number;
      lineContent: string;  // the full line text
    }>;
  }>;
  totalMatches: number;
  truncated: boolean;  // true if maxResults was hit
}
```

Implementation: Walk the directory tree, skip ignored dirs and binary files, read text files and search line by line. Skip files over 1MB. Limit matches per file to 20.

### 5. Route registration
Register the new routes in `apps/orchestrator-server/src/index.ts` alongside the existing route registrations.

## Determining the workspace root
The server needs to know the workspace root path. Check how the server is initialized â€” look at the server config/context for a workspace path or cwd. If none exists, use `process.cwd()` as the workspace root. Store it on the Hono context or in a shared config so routes can access it.

## Goal
Replace the browser File System Access API (FSAPI) based workspace hook with a server-backed implementation that reads/writes files through the orchestrator-server HTTP API. Remove all FSAPI code.

## Context
The editor currently uses FSAPI (`showDirectoryPicker`, `FileSystemFileHandle`, etc.) via the `useFileSystemAccess` hook. This is being replaced because:
- FSAPI only works in Chromium browsers
- FSAPI can't support server-side LSP module resolution
- The orchestrator-server now has filesystem routes (task dependency)

The server routes provide: `GET /api/workspace/tree`, `GET /api/workspace/file?path=...`, `PUT /api/workspace/file`, `POST /api/workspace/search`.

## Changes

### 1. Create new hook: `apps/orchestrator-web/src/hooks/useServerWorkspace.ts`

Replace `useFileSystemAccess.ts` with a new hook that has the **same return type interface** so consumers don't break.

```ts
interface UseServerWorkspaceReturn {
  // Always true â€” server is always available (no browser API check needed)
  isSupported: true;
  // Whether workspace tree has been loaded
  isOpen: boolean;
  // Workspace name (derived from root dir name in tree response)
  workspaceName: string | null;
  // File tree entries
  entries: FileEntry[];
  // Loading state
  isLoading: boolean;
  // Error state
  error: string | null;
  // Load/refresh the workspace tree
  openWorkspace: () => Promise<void>;
  // Clear workspace state
  closeWorkspace: () => void;
  // Refresh the file tree
  refreshTree: () => Promise<void>;
  // Read a file by its entry
  readFile: (entry: FileEntry) => Promise<FileReadResult>;
  // Read a file by path
  readFileByPath: (path: string) => Promise<FileReadResult | null>;
  // Write file content
  writeFile: (entry: FileEntry, content: string) => Promise<FileWriteResult>;
}
```

The `FileEntry`, `FileReadResult`, and `FileWriteResult` types should match what the server returns (see task el-42o2 for the route response shapes). Keep the types compatible with what the editor components expect â€” check `FileSystemEntry` in the old hook and map accordingly.

Key differences from FSAPI version:
- `isSupported` is always `true`
- `openWorkspace()` fetches the tree from `GET /api/workspace/tree` instead of calling `showDirectoryPicker()`. Call it automatically on mount (no user gesture needed â€” server always has access).
- `readFile()` calls `GET /api/workspace/file?path=entry.path`
- `writeFile()` calls `PUT /api/workspace/file` with `{ path, content }`
- No file handles, no permission prompts, no browser API detection

Use `@tanstack/react-query` for the tree fetch (the app already uses it) with a reasonable staleTime (30s).

### 2. Update WorkspaceContext: `apps/orchestrator-web/src/contexts/WorkspaceContext.tsx`

Update the context to use `useServerWorkspace` instead of `useFileSystemAccess`. Update the type exports. The context re-exports `FileSystemEntry`, `FileReadResult`, `FileWriteResult` â€” update these to the new types.

### 3. Update file content search: `apps/orchestrator-web/src/hooks/useFileContentSearch.ts`

Replace the client-side file-by-file search with a call to `POST /api/workspace/search`. The server does the searching now. The hook should:
- Accept the same search params (query, isRegex, caseSensitive, wholeWord)
- Call the server search endpoint
- Return results in the same format the UI expects

### 4. Update EditorFileTree: `apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/editor/EditorFileTree.tsx`

Update the `FileTreeNodeData` interface â€” remove the `fsEntry?: FileSystemEntry` field (which holds FSAPI handles). Instead, use the server's `FileEntry` type. The tree nodes just need `path` to identify files for reading.

### 5. Update FileEditorPage: `apps/orchestrator-web/src/routes/editor/index.tsx`

- Remove the 'Open Local Workspace' button and directory picker UI since the workspace auto-loads from the server
- Remove the `isSupported` conditional checks (always supported now)
- The file source toggle (Local / Docs) can stay â€” 'workspace' now means 'server filesystem' instead of 'FSAPI'. But remove any FSAPI-specific UI (permission prompts, 'File System Access API not supported' message)
- File reading/writing already goes through `useWorkspace()` so it auto-switches to server calls

### 6. Update other consumers
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/command/FileContentSearch.tsx` â€” remove `isSupported` checks
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/command/QuickFileOpen.tsx` â€” remove `isSupported` checks
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/editor/EditorSearchPanel.tsx` â€” remove `isSupported` checks

### 7. Delete FSAPI code
- Delete `apps/orchestrator-web/src/hooks/useFileSystemAccess.ts`
- Remove the FSAPI browser type definitions from `apps/orchestrator-web/src/vite-env.d.ts` (lines 13-95 defining FileSystemHandle, FileSystemFileHandle, etc.)
- Remove any unused imports of FSAPI types

## Goal
Add server-side language servers that communicate with the Monaco editor over WebSocket. This gives the editor real LSP features: module resolution, go-to-definition, hover types, diagnostics, and autocompletion â€” all with full filesystem access. Support multiple languages via a pluggable architecture.

## Context
The editor currently relies on Monaco's built-in TypeScript worker, which only knows about files loaded as editor models. It can't resolve imports because it has no filesystem access. By running language servers on the orchestrator-server and bridging them to the browser via WebSocket, the LSP gets full access to the workspace, node_modules, tsconfig.json, etc.

The Vite dev server already proxies /ws to the orchestrator-server (see apps/orchestrator-web/vite.config.ts line 28-32).

## Supported Language Servers

Build a pluggable architecture that supports multiple language servers. Each server is defined by a config object:

```ts
interface LanguageServerConfig {
  id: string;                    // e.g., 'typescript', 'python', 'rust'
  name: string;                  // display name
  command: string;               // binary to spawn
  args: string[];                // command arguments
  languages: string[];           // Monaco language IDs this server handles
  /** Check if this server's toolchain is installed */
  isAvailable: () => Promise<boolean>;
}
```

### Language servers to include:

1. **TypeScript/JavaScript** â€” `typescript-language-server --stdio`
   - Languages: typescript, javascript, typescriptreact, javascriptreact
   - Availability: check for typescript-language-server in PATH or node_modules/.bin
   - Install: pnpm add -D typescript-language-server typescript in orchestrator-server

2. **Python** â€” `pyright-langserver --stdio` (Pyright is faster and more reliable than pylsp)
   - Languages: python
   - Availability: check for pyright-langserver in PATH (pip install pyright)
   - Don't install â€” check availability at runtime and skip gracefully if not found

3. **Rust** â€” `rust-analyzer`
   - Languages: rust
   - Availability: check for rust-analyzer in PATH (rustup component add rust-analyzer)
   - Don't install â€” check availability at runtime

4. **Go** â€” `gopls serve`
   - Languages: go
   - Availability: check for gopls in PATH (go install golang.org/x/tools/gopls@latest)
   - Don't install â€” check availability at runtime

5. **CSS/HTML/JSON** â€” vscode-css-languageserver --stdio, vscode-html-languageserver --stdio, vscode-json-languageserver --stdio
   - Languages: css/scss/less, html, json/jsonc
   - These are npm packages: vscode-langservers-extracted
   - Install: pnpm add -D vscode-langservers-extracted in orchestrator-server
   - Availability: always (installed as dependency)

For servers that aren't installed (Python, Rust, Go), the system should **gracefully degrade** â€” no LSP features for those languages, no errors. Log which servers are available at startup.

## Implementation

### 1. Server-side: Language server manager
**File:** apps/orchestrator-server/src/services/lsp-manager.ts

Create a manager that spawns and manages language server child processes:
- Registry of LanguageServerConfig entries
- On startup (or on first request), check which servers are available
- Spawn server processes on demand (when a file of that language is first opened)
- Each server communicates over stdio using LSP (JSON-RPC with Content-Length headers)
- Handle lifecycle: start, stop, restart on crash
- One instance per language server (each serves all files of its languages)
- Expose a method: getServerForLanguage(languageId: string): ChildProcess | null

### 2. Server-side: WebSocket-to-LSP bridge
**File:** apps/orchestrator-server/src/routes/lsp-websocket.ts (or extend existing websocket.ts)

Add a WebSocket endpoint at /ws/lsp:
- Client connects with a query param specifying the language: /ws/lsp?language=typescript
- Look up the appropriate language server via the manager
- Forward messages bidirectionally:
  - WebSocket -> prepend Content-Length header -> language server stdin
  - Language server stdout -> strip Content-Length header -> WebSocket
- Handle disconnection: keep the language server running (it can serve multiple reconnects)
- Return an error if no server is available for the requested language

### 3. Server-side: LSP status endpoint

GET /api/lsp/status

Response:
```ts
{
  servers: Array<{
    id: string;
    name: string;
    languages: string[];
    available: boolean;     // is the binary installed?
    running: boolean;       // is the process currently running?
  }>;
}
```

The frontend uses this to show which languages have LSP support in the editor toolbar.

### 4. Frontend: Install and configure monaco-languageclient
Package: apps/orchestrator-web

Install: pnpm add monaco-languageclient vscode-languageclient vscode-ws-jsonrpc

### 5. Frontend: LSP client module
**File:** apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lsp-client.ts (new file)

Create a multi-language LSP client manager:
- Map of active language clients by language ID
- connectLsp(language) function: open WebSocket to /ws/lsp?language=X, create MessageConnection, create MonacoLanguageClient, start it
- disconnectLsp(language) and disconnectAll() functions

### 6. Frontend: Initialize LSP on editor mount
**File:** apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/editor/LspMonacoEditor.tsx

In the editor's onMount callback:
- Check if the current file's language has an available LSP (fetch /api/lsp/status, cache it)
- If available, call connectLsp(language)
- Handle reconnection if WebSocket drops

### 7. Frontend: Update LSP status indicator
**File:** apps/orchestrator-web/src/routes/editor/index.tsx

Replace the hardcoded TS/JS LSP badge (~line 833) with a dynamic check:
- Fetch available servers from /api/lsp/status
- Show LSP badge for any language with available+running server
- Show gray indicator if server binary isn't installed

### 8. LSP file URI mapping
The LSP server works with file:// URIs. Monaco models may use different URIs. The language client needs URI mapping:
- Use the file's actual workspace path as the Monaco model URI where possible
- Configure MonacoLanguageClient's URI mapper
- Workspace root path from /api/lsp/status or a config endpoint

## Goal
Three focused fixes to the editor tab bar UX. All changes are in two files:
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/editor/EditorTabBar.tsx` (fixes 1 and 2)
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/routes/editor/index.tsx` (fix 3)

## Fix 1: Close button visibility on active tab

**Current behavior:** The close (X) button is hidden on all tabs and only appears on hover (unless the tab is dirty). This means users don't know the close button exists.

**Desired behavior:** The close button should ALWAYS be visible on the **active** tab. For inactive tabs, it should remain hidden until hover (current behavior is fine for inactive).

**File:** `EditorTabBar.tsx`, in the `TabItem` component (~line 239-253)

Change the close button opacity logic. Currently:
```tsx
className={`
  ...
  ${tab.isDirty
    ? 'opacity-100'
    : 'opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100'
  }
  ...
`}
```

Change to:
```tsx
className={`
  ...
  ${(tab.isDirty || isActive)
    ? 'opacity-100'
    : 'opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100'
  }
  ...
`}
```

This makes the X visible when the tab is dirty OR when the tab is active.

## Fix 2: Active tab border color

**Current behavior:** There is a blue (primary color) border on top of inactive tabs, and a transparent/standard border on the active tab. This is backwards.

**Desired behavior:** The **active** tab should have the blue/primary border on top. Inactive tabs should have the standard editor border color (not transparent, not blue).

**File:** `EditorTabBar.tsx`, in the `TabItem` component (~line 205-214)

Currently:
```tsx
${isActive
  ? 'bg-[var(--color-surface)] border-t-2 border-t-[var(--color-primary)]'
  : 'bg-[var(--color-surface-hover)] border-t-2 border-t-transparent hover:bg-[var(--color-surface)]'
}
```

Verify in the browser which tab actually shows the blue border. If the code looks correct but the visual is wrong, there may be a CSS specificity issue â€” the `border-r border-[var(--color-border)]` classes applied to all tabs (line 207) might override the `border-t` color. Debug by inspecting in the browser.

If the code is already correct (active = primary, inactive = transparent), the fix may be:
- Ensure `border-t-2` is `border-t-2` not `border-t` (needs 2px to be visible)
- Ensure `border-t-[var(--color-primary)]` isn't being overridden by the generic `border-[var(--color-border)]` â€” Tailwind's `border-[color]` sets all border colors. Fix by using specific sides: keep `border-r border-r-[var(--color-border)]` instead of `border-r border-[var(--color-border)]`.

The inactive tabs should use the standard border color on top (not transparent):
```tsx
${isActive
  ? 'bg-[var(--color-surface)] border-t-2 border-t-[var(--color-primary)]'
  : 'bg-[var(--color-surface-hover)] border-t-2 border-t-[var(--color-border)] hover:bg-[var(--color-surface)]'
}
```

## Fix 3: Tab replacement logic (replace active non-dirty tab)

**Current behavior:** When opening a new file, the code searches for ANY tab with `isPreview && !isDirty` to replace. This means it might replace a tab that isn't the currently active one, which is confusing.

**Desired behavior:** When opening a new file:
- If the **currently active** tab is not dirty â†’ replace it with the new file
- If the currently active tab IS dirty â†’ open the new file in a new tab
- The `isPreview` flag should NOT be used for this logic. What matters is whether the active tab is dirty or not.

**File:** `apps/orchestrator-web/src/routes/editor/index.tsx`

There are THREE places where tabs are created/replaced â€” all need the same fix:

### 3a. Document loading useEffect (~line 263-303)
Replace:
```tsx
// Find preview tab to replace
const previewIndex = prevTabs.findIndex(t => t.isPreview && !t.isDirty);
```
With logic that finds the currently active tab and checks if it's dirty:
```tsx
// Replace the active tab if it's not dirty
const activeIndex = prevTabs.findIndex(t => t.id === activeTabId);
if (activeIndex !== -1 && !prevTabs[activeIndex].isDirty) {
  const updated = [...prevTabs];
  updated[activeIndex] = newTab;
  return updated;
}
```

Note: `activeTabId` needs to be accessible in this closure. It's referenced from the component scope, so it should be in the useEffect dependency array (or use a ref).

### 3b. handleSelectFile for workspace files (~line 343-358)
Same change â€” replace the preview tab logic:
```tsx
setTabs(prevTabs => {
  if (pinTab) {
    return [...prevTabs, newTab];
  }
  // Replace the active tab if it's not dirty
  const activeIndex = prevTabs.findIndex(t => t.id === activeTabId);
  if (activeIndex !== -1 && !prevTabs[activeIndex].isDirty) {
    const updated = [...prevTabs];
    updated[activeIndex] = newTab;
    return updated;
  }
  return [...prevTabs, newTab];
});
```

### 3c. Search result navigation (~line 417-426)
Same pattern for when opening a file from search results.

### 3d. Remove isPreview from new tab creation
Since we no longer use `isPreview` for tab replacement, set `isPreview: false` on all new tabs (or remove the field usage). The italic styling for preview tabs can be removed too â€” the new behavior doesn't distinguish preview vs pinned tabs.

## Verification
- `npx turbo run typecheck` must pass
- Open a file â†’ X button is visible on the active tab without hovering
- Switch to another tab â†’ X disappears on the previous tab, appears on the new active tab
- Active tab has a blue top border, inactive tabs have standard border color
- Open file A â†’ then open file B â†’ file A's tab is replaced by B (since A is not dirty)
- Open file A â†’ type something â†’ open file B â†’ B opens in a new tab (A stays because it's dirty)
- Open file A â†’ type something â†’ undo all changes â†’ the tab is still dirty (undo doesn't clear dirty) â†’ opening file B opens a new tab

Found pre-existing issue during review of el-5wl0: TypeScript errors in apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lsp-client.ts - missing dependencies 'monaco-languageclient' and 'vscode-ws-jsonrpc'. ## Problem
The MonacoLanguageClient in `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lsp-client.ts` does not send `rootUri` or `workspaceFolders` in the LSP initialize request. Additionally, `apps/orchestrator-web/tsconfig.json` lacks `paths` mappings for `@elemental/*` packages, so even with rootUri the TS language server can't resolve local module imports.

## Root Causes

### 1. Missing rootUri in LSP initialize request
- `connectLsp()` in `lsp-client.ts:157-164` creates MonacoLanguageClient without rootUri/workspaceFolders
- The comment on line 161 says "rootUri is set via the LSP initialize request by the server" â€” this is backwards, the CLIENT must tell the server
- The workspace root IS available from `/api/lsp/status` (`LspStatusResponse.workspaceRoot`) â€” it's fetched but never used

### 2. Missing tsconfig paths in orchestrator-web
- `apps/orchestrator-web/tsconfig.json` does NOT define `compilerOptions.paths` for `@elemental/*`
- It does NOT extend `../../tsconfig.base.json` (unlike `apps/orchestrator-server/tsconfig.json` which does)
- When the TS language server opens a web app file, it finds this tsconfig and can't resolve `@elemental/core`, `@elemental/sdk`, etc.
- Compare with `apps/orchestrator-server/tsconfig.json` which has full path mappings and works correctly
- At build time Vite handles resolution via its own module resolution, so this gap only manifests in the LSP

## What to Fix

### Fix A: Send rootUri in LSP initialize request
1. In `connectLsp()` (lsp-client.ts), fetch the workspace root from the already-cached `fetchLspStatus()` response
2. Pass `rootUri` (as a `file://` URI) and `workspaceFolders` in the MonacoLanguageClient `clientOptions`
3. Format: `workspaceFolders: [{ uri: 'file:///path/to/workspace', name: 'elemental' }]`

### Fix B: Add paths to orchestrator-web tsconfig.json
Add `@elemental/*` path mappings to `apps/orchestrator-web/tsconfig.json`:
```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "paths": {
      "@elemental/core": ["../../packages/core/src/index.ts"],
      "@elemental/core/*": ["../../packages/core/src/*"],
      "@elemental/storage": ["../../packages/storage/src/index.ts"],
      "@elemental/storage/*": ["../../packages/storage/src/*"],
      "@elemental/sdk": ["../../packages/sdk/src/index.ts"],
      "@elemental/sdk/*": ["../../packages/sdk/src/*"],
      "@elemental/orchestrator-sdk": ["../../packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/index.ts"],
      "@elemental/orchestrator-sdk/*": ["../../packages/orchestrator-sdk/src/*"],
      "@elemental/ui": ["../../packages/ui/src/index.ts"],
      "@elemental/ui/*": ["../../packages/ui/src/*"],
      "@elemental/shared-routes": ["../../packages/shared-routes/src/index.ts"],
      "@elemental/shared-routes/*": ["../../packages/shared-routes/src/*"]
    }
  }
}
```

Use `apps/orchestrator-server/tsconfig.json` as reference for which packages to include. Check `apps/orchestrator-web/package.json` dependencies to see which `@elemental/*` packages are actually used.

**IMPORTANT:** Verify that adding paths does not break `npx turbo run typecheck`. The web app uses `"moduleResolution": "bundler"` which may interact differently with paths than other apps. Run typecheck after the change.

## Key Files
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lsp-client.ts` â€” add rootUri to connectLsp (lines ~120-190)
- `apps/orchestrator-web/tsconfig.json` â€” add paths mappings
- `apps/orchestrator-server/tsconfig.json` â€” reference for correct paths (DO NOT modify)

## Acceptance Criteria
- LSP initialize request includes correct `rootUri` and `workspaceFolders`
- `apps/orchestrator-web/tsconfig.json` has paths for all `@elemental/*` packages it imports
- TypeScript language server can resolve `@elemental/core` and other local imports in web app files
- `npx turbo run typecheck` passes (all 16 targets)
- Existing LSP features (hover, autocomplete) continue working

## Problem
The LSP status icon in the editor header shows gray (not connected) because the external LSP never connects. Additionally, running Monaco's built-in TypeScript worker alongside the external LSP causes duplicate completions and hover info.

## Root Causes

### 1. Monaco Ref Timing Bug â€” LSP never connects
In `LspMonacoEditor.tsx:136-137`, the `useLsp` hook is called with:
```tsx
const { state: lspState } = useLsp({
  monaco: monacoRef.current ?? undefined,  // Always undefined on first render!
  ...
});
```

`monacoRef.current` is only set later in `handleMount` (line 152). Since it's a ref (not state), changing it doesn't trigger a re-render, so the hook never sees the Monaco instance. The auto-connect logic in `use-lsp.ts:158` checks `!monacoInstance` and bails out.

### 2. Dual Language Services â€” duplicate results when LSP connects
Monaco merges providers from multiple sources. With both the built-in TS worker AND external LSP active:
- **Completions**: Every autocomplete item appears twice in the dropdown
- **Hover**: Overlapping hover info from both sources
- **Diagnostics**: Separate "owner" strings so they coexist (no visual duplication)
- **Definitions, references, etc.**: All duplicated

### 3. No Disconnect Detection
When the WebSocket closes (`lsp-client.ts:184-189`), the `activeClients` map is cleaned up but nothing notifies the React hook. The sync effect in `use-lsp.ts:185-192` only runs when its dependencies change, which doesn't happen on socket close.

## What to Fix

### Part A: Fix Monaco instance timing
1. In `LspMonacoEditor.tsx`: Convert the Monaco instance from a ref to state (or add a state trigger alongside the ref) so that when `handleMount` fires, the component re-renders and `useLsp` receives the actual Monaco instance
2. Ensure no infinite re-render loops

### Part B: Disable built-in TS features when LSP is connected
Use `setModeConfiguration()` to selectively disable Monaco's built-in TypeScript features when the external LSP takes over. This avoids duplicate completions, hover, etc.

```typescript
// When LSP connects for a TS/JS language:
const defaults = monaco.languages.typescript.typescriptDefaults; // or javascriptDefaults
defaults.setModeConfiguration({
  completionItems: false,
  hovers: false,
  diagnostics: false,
  definitions: false,
  references: false,
  documentHighlights: false,
  rename: false,
  codeActions: false,
  signatureHelp: false,
  // Keep these for basic editor UX
  selectionRanges: true,
  foldingRanges: true,
});
```

**IMPORTANT behavioral requirements:**
- Only disable built-in features when LSP is CONNECTED for that language
- If LSP disconnects or is unavailable, RE-ENABLE built-in features as fallback
- Apply to both `typescriptDefaults` and `javascriptDefaults` as appropriate based on the file language
- This should be done in a useEffect that reacts to `lspState` changes

### Part C: Fix disconnect detection
Add a mechanism to detect WebSocket disconnects promptly. Options:
- A polling interval (e.g., every 3-5 seconds check `getLspConnectionState`)
- Or add a subscription/callback mechanism to `lsp-client.ts` that the hook listens to for connection state changes

This is important because Part B needs to re-enable built-in features on disconnect.

## Key Files
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/editor/LspMonacoEditor.tsx` â€” fix Monaco instance timing + add setModeConfiguration
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/use-lsp.ts` â€” fix disconnect detection
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lsp-client.ts` â€” optionally add connection state change callbacks

## Acceptance Criteria
- When opening a TypeScript file, the LSP status icon turns green (connected) within a few seconds
- Autocomplete dropdown shows each item only ONCE (no duplicates from dual providers)
- Hover info appears once (not duplicated)
- If the WebSocket disconnects, the icon changes from green to gray/red within 5 seconds AND built-in TS features are re-enabled
- If LSP is unavailable for a language, built-in features remain active as fallback
- No infinite re-render loops from the state change
- The editor still renders and works correctly while LSP is connecting

## Documentation
- Search workspace docs before starting: `el document search "LSP"`, `el document search "editor"`, `el document search "monaco"`
- Update the LSP Integration Reference document (el-5g65) with notes on setModeConfiguration and dual-provider strategy
- Update Documentation Directory (el-30yb) if new docs are created
- Add any new documents to the Documentation library: `el library add el-2rig <doc-id>`

## Problem
The `MonacoLanguageClient` (from `monaco-languageclient` v10.7.0) constructor crashes with:
```
Error: Default api is not ready yet, do not forget to import 'vscode/localExtensionHost'
and wait for services initialization
```

This is because `monaco-languageclient` v10.x depends on `@codingame/monaco-vscode-api` which requires VSCode API services to be initialized before creating any language client. The project never calls `initialize()`.

Additionally, `getLocalBinPath()` in `lsp-manager.ts` resolved to the wrong directory (`apps/node_modules/.bin` instead of `apps/orchestrator-server/node_modules/.bin`) because it used `../../../` instead of `../../` from `src/services/`. This has already been fixed in the working tree â€” commit the fix.

## What to Fix

### Part A: Initialize VSCode API services for monaco-languageclient v10.x

The `@codingame/monaco-vscode-api` package (already installed as a dependency of `monaco-languageclient`) requires calling `initialize()` before creating a `MonacoLanguageClient`.

Add a one-time service initialization call. This must happen BEFORE `new MonacoLanguageClient()` is called. The recommended approach:

1. Create a new module `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/init-services.ts` that:
   - Imports `initialize` from `@codingame/monaco-vscode-api/services`
   - Imports the necessary service overrides from the `@codingame/monaco-vscode-*-service-override` packages (these are already installed as dependencies of `monaco-languageclient`)
   - Calls `initialize()` once and caches the promise
   - Exports an `ensureServicesInitialized()` function that returns the cached promise

2. The minimum required service overrides for LSP to work (check what `monaco-languageclient` lists in its dependencies):
   ```typescript
   import getModelServiceOverride from '@codingame/monaco-vscode-model-service-override';
   import getEditorServiceOverride from '@codingame/monaco-vscode-editor-service-override';
   import getLanguagesServiceOverride from '@codingame/monaco-vscode-languages-service-override';
   import getThemeServiceOverride from '@codingame/monaco-vscode-theme-service-override';
   import getTextmateServiceOverride from '@codingame/monaco-vscode-textmate-service-override';
   import getConfigurationServiceOverride from '@codingame/monaco-vscode-configuration-service-override';

   const initPromise = initialize({
     ...getModelServiceOverride(),
     ...getEditorServiceOverride(/* openEditor callback */),
     ...getLanguagesServiceOverride(),
     ...getThemeServiceOverride(),
     ...getTextmateServiceOverride(),
     ...getConfigurationServiceOverride(),
   });

   export async function ensureServicesInitialized() {
     return initPromise;
   }
   ```

3. In `lsp-client.ts`, call `await ensureServicesInitialized()` before `new MonacoLanguageClient()` in the `connectLsp()` function.

**IMPORTANT NOTES:**
- The `@codingame/monaco-vscode-api` services may conflict with `@monaco-editor/react`'s default Monaco loader. You may need to configure `@monaco-editor/react`'s `loader` to use the same Monaco instance. Check if `@codingame/monaco-vscode-editor-api` provides its own Monaco that should replace `monaco-editor`.
- Look at the `monaco-languageclient` GitHub repo examples for the correct v10.x initialization pattern â€” search for examples in the repo at `TypeFox/monaco-languageclient`.
- If the `@codingame/monaco-vscode-*` service overrides cause issues with `@monaco-editor/react`, the alternative is to downgrade `monaco-languageclient` to v8.x which works with vanilla Monaco. Check `npm view monaco-languageclient@8 version` for the latest v8. v8 does NOT require VSCode service initialization.
- If downgrading, also adjust the `MonacoLanguageClient` constructor â€” the v8 API may differ slightly from v10.

### Part B: Commit the getLocalBinPath fix

The fix to `lsp-manager.ts` line 75 (changing `../../../` to `../../`) is already in the working tree. Include it in the commit.

### Part C: Verify the vscode-css/html/json language servers

The LSP status API also shows CSS, HTML, and JSON servers as `"available": false`. These packages (`vscode-css-language-server`, `vscode-html-language-server`, `vscode-json-language-server`) are NOT in `apps/orchestrator-server/package.json`. Check if they should be added as dependencies. If so, add them. If not (because those languages don't need LSP in this project), that's fine â€” just verify the lsp-manager doesn't break when they're unavailable.

## Key Files
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lsp-client.ts` â€” add `await ensureServicesInitialized()` before `new MonacoLanguageClient()`
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/init-services.ts` â€” NEW FILE for VSCode service initialization
- `apps/orchestrator-server/src/services/lsp-manager.ts` â€” getLocalBinPath fix already in working tree
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/components/editor/LspMonacoEditor.tsx` â€” may need to adjust `@monaco-editor/react` loader configuration

## Testing
After the fix, verify by opening the orchestrator-web app at http://localhost:5174/editor:
1. Navigate to Editor
2. Click on a TypeScript file (e.g., packages > core > src > index.ts)
3. Check browser console for `[lsp-client]` logs â€” should see "WebSocket connected" and "Language client started" WITHOUT the "Default api is not ready" error
4. The LSP status indicator next to "TypeScript" in the editor header should turn GREEN
5. No false "Cannot find module" error markers in the editor

Also verify:

Task assigned: Initialize VSCode API services for monaco-languageclient v10.x and fix getLocalBinPath [Priority: 1]

## Problem
`monaco-languageclient` v10.x (and v8.x) requires `@codingame/monaco-vscode-api` service initialization which is incompatible with `@monaco-editor/react`. The `initialize()` call from `@codingame/monaco-vscode-api` replaces Monaco's internal service registry, which causes the `@monaco-editor/react` editor component to unmount and lose state. This cannot be fixed by timing the initialization earlier â€” the two systems are fundamentally incompatible.

## Solution
Replace `MonacoLanguageClient` with a **lightweight LSP client** that:
1. Uses `vscode-ws-jsonrpc` (already installed, no VSCode dependency) for JSON-RPC over WebSocket
2. Manually registers Monaco language providers (completion, hover, diagnostics, definitions)
3. Translates between LSP protocol messages and Monaco's provider interfaces
4. Works with vanilla `monaco-editor` and `@monaco-editor/react` without any `@codingame/monaco-vscode-*` packages

## Architecture

### WebSocket Layer (keep existing)
- `vscode-ws-jsonrpc` provides `WebSocketMessageReader`/`WebSocketMessageWriter` â€” reuse these
- Keep the existing `getLspWebSocketUrl()` and WebSocket connection logic from `lsp-client.ts`

### JSON-RPC Layer
Use `vscode-jsonrpc` (dependency of `vscode-ws-jsonrpc`) to create a `MessageConnection`:
```typescript
import { createMessageConnection } from 'vscode-jsonrpc';
import { WebSocketMessageReader, WebSocketMessageWriter, toSocket } from 'vscode-ws-jsonrpc';

const webSocket = new WebSocket(url);
const socket = toSocket(webSocket);
const reader = new WebSocketMessageReader(socket);
const writer = new WebSocketMessageWriter(socket);
const connection = createMessageConnection(reader, writer);
connection.listen();
```

### LSP Protocol Layer
Use `vscode-languageserver-protocol` (already installed as transitive dep) for typed LSP request/notification types:
```typescript
import {
  InitializeRequest, InitializeParams,
  CompletionRequest, CompletionParams,
  HoverRequest, HoverParams,
  DidOpenTextDocumentNotification,
  DidChangeTextDocumentNotification,
  PublishDiagnosticsNotification,
  // etc.
} from 'vscode-languageserver-protocol';
```

### Monaco Provider Registration
Register providers with Monaco directly. Map LSP responses to Monaco's format:

1. **Diagnostics**: Listen for `textDocument/publishDiagnostics` notification, convert to `monaco.editor.setModelMarkers()`
2. **Completion**: Register `monaco.languages.registerCompletionItemProvider()`, send `textDocument/completion` request
3. **Hover**: Register `monaco.languages.registerHoverProvider()`, send `textDocument/hover` request
4. **Go to Definition**: Register `monaco.languages.registerDefinitionProvider()`, send `textDocument/definition` request

### Document Sync
Track open documents and send `textDocument/didOpen` and `textDocument/didChange` notifications to the language server when editor content changes.

## Implementation Steps

### Step 1: Create lightweight LSP client module
Create `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lightweight-client.ts`:
- Initialize LSP connection (JSON-RPC over WebSocket)
- Send `initialize` request with proper `rootUri` and `workspaceFolders` (from workspace root fetched via `/api/lsp/status`)
- Send `initialized` notification
- Handle `textDocument/publishDiagnostics` notification â†’ convert to Monaco markers
- Implement `textDocument/completion` â†’ Monaco completion provider
- Implement `textDocument/hover` â†’ Monaco hover provider
- Send `textDocument/didOpen` and `textDocument/didChange` notifications

### Step 2: Update lsp-client.ts
Replace `MonacoLanguageClient` usage with the lightweight client:
- Remove `import { MonacoLanguageClient } from 'monaco-languageclient'`
- Use `createMessageConnection` from `vscode-jsonrpc` instead
- Keep the existing connection state management (subscribeToConnectionState, activeClients map)
- Keep the existing `fetchLspStatus`, `getLspWebSocketUrl` etc.

### Step 3: Remove monaco-languageclient dependency
- Remove `monaco-languageclient` from `apps/orchestrator-web/package.json`
- Remove `@codingame/monaco-vscode-api`, `@codingame/monaco-vscode-model-service-override`, `@codingame/monaco-vscode-languages-service-override` from package.json
- Delete `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/init-services.ts` if it exists
- Keep `vscode-ws-jsonrpc` (needed for WebSocket transport)
- Add `vscode-languageserver-protocol` to dependencies if not already direct

### Step 4: Update Monaco integration
In `LspMonacoEditor.tsx` or `use-lsp.ts`:
- Pass the Monaco instance to the lightweight client so it can register providers
- When LSP connects, register completion/hover/diagnostics/definition providers
- When LSP disconnects, dispose the registered providers
- Keep the `setModeConfiguration` logic to disable built-in TS features when LSP is connected

## Key Files to Modify
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lightweight-client.ts` â€” NEW: lightweight LSP client
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/lsp-client.ts` â€” replace MonacoLanguageClient
- `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/monaco-lsp/use-lsp.ts` â€” update to pass Monaco instance to client
- `apps/orchestrator-web/package.json` â€” remove monaco-languageclient, add vscode-languageserver-protocol

## LSP â†” Monaco Type Conversion Reference

### Diagnostics (server â†’ client push)
```typescript
// LSP Diagnostic â†’ Monaco IMarkerData
function toMonacoMarker(diagnostic: Diagnostic): monaco.editor.IMarkerData {
  return {
    severity: toMonacoSeverity(diagnostic.severity),
    message: diagnostic.message,
    startLineNumber: diagnostic.range.start.line + 1,  // LSP is 0-based, Monaco is 1-based
    startColumn: diagnostic.range.start.character + 1,
    endLineNumber: diagnostic.range.end.line + 1,
    endColumn: diagnostic.range.end.character + 1,
    source: diagnostic.source,
    code: typeof diagnostic.code === 'number' ? String(diagnostic.code) : diagnostic.code,
  };
}
```

### Completion (client â†’ server request)
```typescript
// Monaco Position â†’ LSP CompletionParams
const params: CompletionParams = {
  textDocument: { uri: model.uri.toString() },
  position: { line: position.lineNumber - 1, character: position.column - 1 },
};
// LSP CompletionItem â†’ Monaco CompletionItem conversion needed
```

### Hover (client â†’ server request)
```typescript
// LSP Hover â†’ Monaco Hover
const params: HoverParams = {
  textDocument: { uri: model.uri.toString() },
  position: { line: position.lineNumber - 1, character: position.column - 1 },
};
```

## Acceptance Criteria

## Context

To install extensions from OpenVSX, we need to parse VSIX files (ZIP archives containing extension code and metadata) and filter to only declarative extensions (themes, grammars, snippets) that are safe to load without a full extension host.

## What to Do

### New file: `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/openvsx/vsix-parser.ts`

1. Add `jszip` dependency to `apps/orchestrator-web/package.json`
2. Create a `parseVsix(buffer: ArrayBuffer)` function that:
   - Unzips the VSIX using jszip
   - Reads `extension/package.json` to get the manifest
   - Extracts files referenced in `contributes.themes`, `contributes.grammars`, `contributes.snippets`
   - Returns a structured result: `{ manifest, contributedFiles: Map<string, Uint8Array> }`

### Compatibility filter: `isDeclarativeExtension(manifest)`

Only allow installation if:
- No `main` or `browser` entry point (extension runs code â†’ reject)
- `contributes` only contains supported keys: `themes`, `grammars`, `languages`, `snippets`, `iconThemes`, `productIconThemes`
- Reject if `contributes` contains: `commands`, `debuggers`, `views`, `menus`, `keybindings`, `taskDefinitions`, `webview*`, etc.
- Check `engines.vscode` â€” warn or reject if it requires an API version beyond what @codingame/monaco-vscode-api supports

### Export types

```typescript
interface ParsedExtension {
  manifest: ExtensionManifest;
  contributedFiles: Map<string, Uint8Array>;  // path â†’ file contents
}

interface ExtensionManifest {
  name: string;
  publisher: string;
  version: string;
  displayName?: string;
  description?: string;
  categories?: string[];
  contributes?: ExtensionContributes;
  engines?: { vscode?: string };
  icon?: string;
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- Can parse a real VSIX file (test with Dracula theme or similar small theme extension)
- `isDeclarativeExtension` correctly accepts theme/grammar-only extensions
- `isDeclarativeExtension` correctly rejects extensions with `main`/`browser` or unsupported contributes
- Theme JSON files are correctly extracted from the VSIX
- Grammar (TextMate .tmLanguage.json) files are correctly extracted
- `npx turbo run typecheck` passes
- Unit tests for the compatibility filter

## Context

Installed extensions need to persist across browser sessions. IndexedDB is the right choice for storing extension manifests and their extracted files (theme JSON, grammar JSON, etc.).

## What to Do

### New file: `apps/orchestrator-web/src/lib/openvsx/storage.ts`

Create an IndexedDB storage layer with two object stores:

1. **`installed_extensions`** â€” stores extension manifests + metadata
   - Key: extension ID (`publisher.name`)
   - Value: `{ id, manifest, installedAt, version }`

2. **`extension_files`** â€” stores extracted files from the VSIX
   - Key: compound key `extensionId + "/" + filePath`
   - Value: file content (JSON parsed for .json files, string for others)

### API

```typescript
// Lifecycle
initExtensionStorage(): Promise<void>

// Extensions
saveExtension(id: string, manifest: ExtensionManifest, files: Map<string, Uint8Array>): Promise<void>
removeExtension(id: string): Promise<void>
getInstalledExtensions(): Promise<InstalledExtension[]>
getExtension(id: string): Promise<InstalledExtension | null>

// Files
getExtensionFile(extensionId: string, filePath: string): Promise<Uint8Array | null>
getExtensionFiles(extensionId: string): Promise<Map<string, Uint8Array>>
```

### Implementation Notes

- Use the `idb` library (lightweight IndexedDB wrapper) or a thin native wrapper â€” keep it simple
- Include a DB version number for future schema migrations
- `saveExtension` and `removeExtension` should be transactional (both stores updated atomically)
- Handle the case where IndexedDB is unavailable (private browsing in some browsers) â€” fail gracefully with a console warning

## Acceptance Criteria

- Can save an extension with files, retrieve it, and delete it
- Data persists across page reloads
- Transactional: partial saves don't leave orphaned data
- Graceful degradation if IndexedDB is unavailable
- `npx turbo run typecheck` passes
- Unit tests for CRUD operations
